title: What is the origin of the phrase, 'used to'? - Quora
tags: What Is the Origin of X?
Etymology of English Phrases (Origin or History of English Phrases)

response.answer_text: You are correct to point out that the idiom "used to" is used in two ways. The two usages both stem from an archaic definition of "use" as "habit". As an example of this archaic usage, there is a famous line from Shakespeare's least famous play: "How use doth breed habit in a man!" (Two Gentlemen 5:IV), which suggests that a "use" is a weaker form of a "habit".  This usage explains the second idiom in your question. "I am used to drugs" means that I have used drugs and therefore drugs have become a habit. The sentence in your question "I am used to seeing kites in the sky" can be interpreted as "I am habituated to seeing kites in the sky". In both cases, the connection is hard to see because we do not see the two nouns "use"-"habit" but instead see the two passives "am used"-"am habituated". The explanation of the first idiom ("I used to run") is harder. This idiom represents (1) the presumption that you ran at some point and (2) the conclusion that you do not run anymore. There is no well accepted consensus on how this interpretation came about, but based on patterns of usage change found in other words, here is my conjecture (starting now, I am making things up as I go, but I am reasonably confident about what I am saying): I think "used to" in the "I used to run" sense came about as (simple past) + (noun infinitive). Here is why. First, consider the sentence "I used drugs". As a hint that we are going in the right direction, this has the same interpretation as what we are looking for: (1) the presumption that you used drugs at some point and (2) the conclusion that you do not use drugs anymore. Now, recall that infinitives ("to run", "to eat") can be used as nouns: in the phrase "to err is human; to forgive is divine", "to err" and "to forgive" both serve as nouns, and as the subjects of their respective clauses (I could just as well say "Raj is human; God is divine"). Therefore, what if we substitute one noun "drugs" in the sentence "I used drugs" with another noun, namely "to run"? We get "I used to run". If we interpret "use" as "habit", we have "I was habituated with drugs" and "I was habituated to run". Here, the logical breakdown of the sentence is "(I used) (to run)": the thing I formerly "used" was running. But over time, phrases of the form "(I used) (to verb)" resulted in the construction being parsed as "(I used to) (verb)", and so we now think of "I used to" as its own idiom which means "I formerly". One interesting corollary to my conjecture above: phrases like "I used to use drugs" (which I hear often) are redundant. We went from "I used drugs" (in the past, drugs were my habit) to "I used to use drugs" (in the past, the habit of using drugs was my habit).

First, let’s look at “use” as a noun: It appeared in English in the early 13th century with the meaning of “act of employing” or as we might say somewhat circularly, “act of making use of” something. It entered English from Anglo-French and Old French with the sense of “custom, practice, usage,” etc. (Online Etymology Dictionary)It traces back to Latin usus, “use, custom, practice, skill, habit,” etc. Usus itself came from the past participle of uti, “make use of profit by, take advantage of.” (Online Etymology Dictionary)How about “use” as a verb? “Use” as a verb entered contemporaneously with the noun usage, that is in the early 13th century, coming from Old French user “employ, make use of, practice, frequent, etc. (Online Etymology Dictionary)Again back to Latin. Old French user traced to Vulgar Latin (which just means a common form, not an obscene one; Vulgar Latin - Wikipedia) form. As mentioned above it was a form of the stem of the Latin past participle uti, which in turn is found in Old Latin oeti with a very similar meaning (e.g., “use, employ, exercise, perform,” etc.). (Online Etymology Dictionary)(Note: I believe modern French might, er, “use” the verb utiliser rather than user but a French speaker could confirm that one way or the other. My own French is quite modest. I’ve heard user with more of a sense like “to wear” though one can see the semantic relationship between ideas like “wear” and “make use of.”)The Latin roots get into an area of verbal structure or logic called frequentative. That refers to a type of verbal usage that shows repeated, habitual, and often intense action. (Frequentative definition and meaning | Collins English Dictionary)That frequentative sense shows up, for example, in the Spanish imperfect tense (Spanish Imperfect Tense | SpanishDict) which is often translated as “used to” or “would” + verb (that tense has other uses too, but it gives a hint for the answer to this question).Some examples of those various meanings “The crook used them” versus “the crook used a screwdriver.” The first harks back to that sense of manipulate or take advantage. The second is just neutral employment of a tool.“He used drugs” is simple past tense and “used” might or might not indicate an ongoing or repetitive activity. “He used drugs one time. That was enough.”Compare, “he used to use drugs.” That clearly indicates a repetitive past activity. It would be odd to say “he used to use drugs.” and then add ? “that was enough” or ? “once was enough.” And you couldn’t say * “he used to use drugs one time/once.”Another sense of “used to” just means “accustomed to.” “She was used to getting up at 6 am” means that was the time she usually got up and she was ij the habit of doing so and habituated to that. Note that “get” has to appear in progressive form since the tense marking is on “used to” and the action is repetitive.You could not say * “she was used to got up …” or * “she was used to get up …” — and that second one is semantically ambiguous, and could flip “used” into its voiced version to mark employment rather than tense with a rather bizarre meaning. Compare, “The alarm clock was used to wake them up even though they hated the sound.”Side fact—”Use” displaced a Germanic word “Use” replaced Old English brucan which meant “use, enjoy the use of,” etc. You can see a cognate in Modern German brauchen “to use, need” (brauchen - Wiktionary). The surviving English word “brook” is rarely heard. It went through phases of meaning “take advantage of” and then “endure, tolerate” something negative. I’ve only heard or read “brook” once or twice in my life in that sense, but it is still around. (brook - Wiktionary)So what does all the above tell us about the answer(s) to the question? What was the source of “used to”? Latin words evolved through French and entered English, displacing the Germanic sourced English “brook.” The core semantics of “use” revolve around “employing something or someone toward some objective” including the repetitive employment of an instrument. “Sails use wind; hunters use weapons; mechanics use tools;” etc. That repetitive use then shows up in a verbal structure “use” + past tense + verb (inf.) to mark past enduring, repetitive, or habitual actions. “She used to sing; they used to dream of a better life; she used to bowl; he used to be a chef;” etc. This usage amounts to what is called imperfect tense (for example as in Spanish as noted above) or see Imperfect - Wikipedia. (Also see Definition of USED TO.) Note that “used to” in this imperfect, tense marking usage is always unvoiced [just] (like “youst”) whereas the purely verbal usage is always voiced [juzd] (like “youzed”) as in “he used the club.” And note that the voiced, past tense usage is transitive. “She used the laser; the girls used their compass to get out of the woods; people use their cars for transportation;” etc. In contrast, the imperfect, tense marking, voiceless “used to” is not transitive. What follows must be a verb. You cannot say * “he used to tool; she used to her voice; they used to rifles to hunt.” And finally, that special use of “used to” to indicate past, repetitive action does not work in present tense. You must use pass tense. You cannot say * “he uses to sing all the time; I use to drive to work; it uses to rain all the time.” In all those preceding cases, the repetitiveness of an action is captured by simple present tense: ““he sings all the time; I drive to work; it rains all the time.”In summary, “used to” is employed to mark some aspects of an imperfective tense, to indicate a past habitual, frequentative, repetitive action. In its evolution, it has become phonologically and syntactically distinct from the simple verb “use.” And furthermore … “Used to” is in effect what is called a marginal modal verb. Notice how closely it functions syntactically and semantically compared to say “would” in (a) “Grandma used to sing the baby to sleep every night” and (b) “Grandma would sing the baby to sleep every night.” (See Used to | Learning English Grammar | Collins Education for example.) Common error—side note In teaching developmental English, I saw common errors like this: * “I use to go shopping every Saturday” rather than the correct “I used to go shopping every Saturday.”There seemed to be three reasons for this type of error.Phonological: “used to” and “use to” are homophones in casual speech. The “d” at the end of “used” is simply the voiced counterpart of the following “t” that starts the “to.” The “d” assimilates to the following “t” and in effect disappears.Not only the “d” becomes voiceless. The “s” does too. Whereas one may “use the tool” [juwz] when you get to the past tense you get a variation: “used the tool” is still voiced [juwzd] but in that English verb frequentative sense it precedes “to” and forms a sort of unit, and the “used” is pronounced [just].By “sort of unit” I mean that the the “used” and “to” are strongly enough associated that they are even pronounced as a unit typically, like [justə].Phonetic: people who were taught to spell phonetically sometimes have trouble with English spelling, for English spelling often does not capture the phonetic or phonemic structure of the language. I would say that to an extent, English uses an orthography that is in great part morphological—and that has its pros and cons.Lack of understanding of the verbal structure: In a case like “I used to go” the verbal structure is not as clear as say “I would like to go” or even “I would go.” Not understanding that the structure is used for a past, repetitive or habitual activity, one can thus overlook that the verb “use” must appear in past tense, and thus has to be “used” and not “use.”
